listDisplay.primary: Tsukuyomi-no-Mikoto - God of the Moon and the Night
listDisplay.secondary: Moon God, Lord of Night, Counter of Time

subtitle: God of the Moon and the Night

gridDisplay.subtitle: God of the Moon and the Night

hoverInfo.quick: The serene moon god forever separated from his sister Amaterasu

gridDisplay.title: Tsukuyomi-no-Mikoto

name: Tsukuyomi-no-Mikoto

search.searchableText: tsukuyomi-no-mikoto moon god night time celestial shinto lunar

description: Tsukuyomi-no-Mikoto is the moon god of Japanese mythology, the serene ruler of night who emerged from Izanagi's right eye during purification. Though born alongside Amaterasu and Susanoo as one of the Three Precious Children, he is the most mysterious and least documented of the trio, eternally separated from his sister the sun goddess.

historicalContext.historicalPeriod: Kojiki (712 CE) and Nihon Shoki (720 CE)
historicalContext.sourceText: Kojiki - Book 1: Cosmological separation of day/night

shrineSites.name: Tsukiyomi Shrine (Tsukiyomi-no-miya)
shrineSites.significance: Part of Ise Shrine complex but separate from Amaterasu's Inner Shrine
shrineSites.notes: Architectural arrangement reflects day/night separation myth

shrineSites.name: Tsukiyomi Shrine (Kyoto)
shrineSites.significance: Important moon god shrine with lunar viewing traditions

shrineSites.name: Matsuo Taisha
shrineSites.significance: Associated with lunar deities and sake brewing

festivalAssociations.name: Tsukimi (Moon Viewing Festival)
festivalAssociations.significance: Popular observance for moon appreciation, offering dango and pampas grass

festivalAssociations.name: Jugoya (Full Moon Night)
festivalAssociations.significance: Most important moon viewing night, honoring the harvest moon

buddhistEquivalents.significance: Part of healing trinities with Yakushi Nyorai and Nikko Bosatsu

imperialConnections.minorStatus: Less prominent in imperial cult than Amaterasu

historicalNotes: Gender ambiguity - sometimes male, sometimes female depending on source
Food scandal (killing Ukemochi) - explains eternal separation from Amaterasu
Lesser prominence reflects patrilineal power dynamics
Influenced by lunar calendar agricultural society needs
Moon counting essential for rice cultivation timing

narratives.title: Birth from Izanagi's Purification
narratives.summary: Born from Izanagi's right eye during his misogi (purification) after fleeing the underworld Yomi. Assigned to rule the night realm alongside Amaterasu's day and Susanoo's seas.
narratives.significance: Establishes the cosmic triad of celestial rulers

narratives.title: The Murder of Ukemochi
narratives.summary: Amaterasu sent Tsukuyomi to visit Ukemochi, the food goddess. When Ukemochi produced a feast by disgorging food from her mouth, nose, and posterior, Tsukuyomi was so disgusted he killed her. From her body grew the five grains, silkworms, and cattle. When Amaterasu learned of the murder, she declared she would never look upon Tsukuyomi again.
narratives.significance: Explains the eternal separation of sun and moon, why they never appear together in the sky

narratives.title: Ruler of the Night Realm
narratives.summary: After the separation, Tsukuyomi was assigned dominion over the night, counting the months and measuring time through the moon's phases. He became the silent guardian of darkness.
narratives.significance: Establishes the lunar calendar and night-time order

practices: Tsukimi (moon viewing) ceremonies with dango offerings
Prayers for good harvests timed by lunar calendar
Night vigils and meditation under the moon
Offerings of white rice, sake, and pampas grass

sacredObjects.name: Susuki (Pampas grass)
sacredObjects.description: Traditional Tsukimi offering representing autumn harvest

sacredObjects.name: Tsukimi Dango
sacredObjects.description: Moon-shaped rice dumplings offered during viewing

sacredAnimals: Rabbit (seen pounding mochi in the moon)

primary.title: Kojiki
primary.author: O no Yasumaro
primary.description: Record of Ancient Matters - brief mention of birth

primary.title: Nihon Shoki
primary.author: Prince Toneri et al.
primary.description: Chronicles of Japan - fuller account including Ukemochi incident

father.name: Izanagi-no-Mikoto
father.relationship: Born from his right eye during purification

siblings.name: Amaterasu-Omikami
siblings.relationship: Sun Goddess, elder sister, born from left eye - eternally separated

siblings.name: Susanoo-no-Mikoto
siblings.relationship: Storm God, younger brother, born from nose

divineRelationships.separated: Amaterasu - they can never appear together due to his killing of Ukemochi
divineRelationships.killed: Ukemochi - the food goddess whose death brought the five grains

symbolism.archetype: Moon Deity - gentle light in darkness, time-keeper, mysterious and remote
